questions.question: Patient with severe abdominal pain. What does the image show?
questions.learning_points:
Free gas (pneumoperitoneum) can be seen on both sides of the bowel wall. This is Rigler’s sign or the double wall sign.
Whenever sharp points or triangles of low density are seen adjacent to loops of bowel, pneumoperitoneum should be suspected.
Note:In patients with an acute abdomen an erect chest X-ray is more sensitive for small volumes of free gas.

questions.question: Patient with history of ulcerative colitis. What radiological finding is shown?
questions.learning_points: Inflammation of the bowel wall leads to thickening of the haustral folds. This results in the radiological sign of thumbprinting, a characteristic finding in patients with active ulcerative colitis.

questions.question: What is the cause of the abnormal calcification?
questions.learning_points:
An irregularly shaped calcified area is located over the left kidney. It resembles a staghorn, hence ‘staghorn calculus’.
The outlines of both kidneys are quite well defined on this image.

questions.question: Patient with abdominal pain. Which statement is true?
options: Chest X-rays are not used in the context of acute abdominal pain
The image shows a good example of Chilaiditi’s phenomenon
There is free intra-abdominal gas visible under the left hemidiaphragm
There is free intra-abdominal gas visible under the right hemidiaphragm
There is free intra-abdominal gas visible under both hemidiaphrams
questions.correct_answer: There is free intra-abdominal gas visible under the left hemidiaphragm
questions.learning_points:
An erect chest X-ray is more sensitive for detection of free gas than an abdominal X-ray.
This image shows a small volume of free gas under the left hemidiaphragm. This may be seen following abdominal surgery, but in the context of a patient presenting with abdominal pain this finding indicates perforation.
This is not the stomach bubble.
Chilaiditi’s syndrome – gas within a loop of bowel located between the liver and the diaphragm – is more typically seen on the right and does not result in formation of a crescent-shaped rim of gas under the diaphragm as is seen in this image.

questions.question: What is the cause of the abnormal calcification?
questions.learning_points:
10-15% of gallstones are calcified sufficiently to be visible on an abdominal X-ray. They have very varied appearances and are frequently asymptomatic – as was the case in this patient.
Note:Ultrasound is the initial investigation of choice for suspected gallstones

questions.question: Patient with acute abdominal pain. What does the X-ray show?
questions.learning_points: The gas pattern is normal in this image. No cause of abdominal pain is visible.

questions.question: 24-year-old patient with suspected appendicitis. What does the image show?
questions.learning_points: Dilated loops of bowel with valvulae conniventes – lines crossing the full width of the bowel – indicates small bowel obstruction.

questions.question: Patient with severe abdominal pain. What is the cause of pain demonstrated on this abdominal X-ray?
questions.learning_points: There is a segment of very dilated gas-filled bowel. The right iliac fossa (RIF) is empty indicating displacement of the caecum. These are typical appearances of caecal volvulus.

questions.question: Patient with abdominal pain. What does the image show?
options: Poor quality image which should be repeated
questions.learning_points:
The bones should be checked whenever viewing an abdominal X-ray. In this image the bones of the spine and pelvis are much too dense.
These are the typical appearances of sclerotic bone metastases. In this case the patient had metastatic prostate cancer.

questions.question: What is the artifact shown in this image?
questions.learning_points:
This patient presented with an obstructed left ureter due to a renal stone. A ureteric stent was inserted – also known as a JJ-stent or a pig-tail catheter– which passes from the renal pelvis to the bladder.
Percutaneous nephrostomy tubes pass through the abdominal wall to the renal pelvis.
